title: Common Food Ingredients
description: Learn the names of common food ingredients in Portuguese, essential for shopping at markets and reading recipes.

grammar.title: Gender of Food Nouns
grammar.content: Food nouns have gender in Portuguese. Most ending in -a are feminine, most ending in -o are masculine. Some are irregular.
examples: Feminine: a carne, a batata, a fruta, a cebola
Masculine: o peixe, o arroz, o queijo, o tomate

grammar.title: Using 'Gosto de' (I Like)
grammar.content: To express food preferences, use 'gosto de' (I like) or 'não gosto de' (I don't like) followed by the food item.
examples: Não gosto de cebola. (I don't like onion.)
Gosto muito de queijo. (I really like cheese.)

grammar.title: Plural Forms
grammar.content: Most nouns add -s for plural. Words ending in -l change to -is. Words ending in -ão have irregular plurals.

exercises.question: What is the Portuguese word for 'chicken'?
exercises.explanation: 'Frango' means chicken. It's one of the most common meats in Portuguese cuisine.

exercises.question: How do you say 'I like fish'?
exercises.explanation: 'Gosto de peixe' means 'I like fish'. Use 'gosto de' followed by the food item.

exercises.question: What is 'azeite'?
exercises.explanation: 'Azeite' is olive oil, an essential ingredient in Portuguese cooking.

exercises.question: Complete: Salada de ____ (Tomato salad)
exercises.explanation: 'Tomate' means tomato. 'Salada de tomate' is a tomato salad.

exercises.question: Which food item is feminine?
exercises.explanation: 'A batata' (potato) is feminine. Notice the article 'a' instead of 'o'.

culturalNotes.title: Portuguese Markets
culturalNotes.content: Portugal has wonderful fresh markets (mercados). The most famous is Mercado da Ribeira in Lisbon. Vendors are friendly and often give samples. It's normal to ask for specific amounts by weight.

culturalNotes.title: Bacalhau - Portuguese Cod
culturalNotes.content: Dried salted cod (bacalhau) is a national treasure with supposedly 365 recipes - one for each day of the year. It's soaked before cooking and appears in many traditional dishes.

culturalNotes.title: Olive Oil Quality
culturalNotes.content: Portugal produces excellent olive oil. Look for 'azeite virgem extra' (extra virgin). Portuguese cuisine uses olive oil generously - it's healthier than butter and adds authentic flavor.
